intro: Diplotaxis ollivieri, commonly known as the African wallflower, is an annual herbaceous plant native to southern Africa. It features a branched stem covered in fine hairs and produces small, bright yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant has alternate, linear leaves that are often covered in a white powdery coating, known as bloom. It thrives in well-drained soils and is drought-tolerant, making it suitable for arid environments. Its flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological importance in its native habitat.
